cit1.CITATION: Small non-coding RNAs are increasingly recognized as key players in post-transcriptional regulation of nearly all regulatory networks in bacteria [1, 2].

cit2.CITATION: Small non-coding RNAs are increasingly recognized as key players in post-transcriptional regulation of nearly all regulatory networks in bacteria [1, 2].

cit3.CITATION: They can bind to the ribosome-binding site, thus occluding it, and inhibiting binding of the ribosome [3].

cit4.CITATION: The decreased mRNA translation rate leaves mRNA unprotected by ribosomes, which can indirectly lead to an increased mRNA decay rate [4].

cit5.CITATION: In addition, mRNA binding can also directly increase mRNA decay rates, by providing double-stranded RNA for cleavage by RNase III or by the sRNA-mediated direct recruitment of RNase E [4, 5].

cit6.CITATION: In addition, mRNA binding can also directly increase mRNA decay rates, by providing double-stranded RNA for cleavage by RNase III or by the sRNA-mediated direct recruitment of RNase E [4, 5].

cit7.CITATION: Positive regulation by trans-encoded sRNAs can also occur: sRNA interaction with a 5′ untranslated region (5′UTR) can disrupt secondary structures that would otherwise inhibit translation, or it can inhibit mRNA degradation by blocking RNase E cleavage sites [3, 6].

cit8.CITATION: Positive regulation by trans-encoded sRNAs can also occur: sRNA interaction with a 5′ untranslated region (5′UTR) can disrupt secondary structures that would otherwise inhibit translation, or it can inhibit mRNA degradation by blocking RNase E cleavage sites [3, 6].

cit9.CITATION: Many trans-encoded sRNA depend on the RNA chaperone Hfq for binding to their cognate targets [7].

cit10.CITATION: Hfq typically needs further distal sequence elements for binding, in Escherichia coli these are multiple A-rich ARN or AAN repeats [7, 8].

cit11.CITATION: Hfq typically needs further distal sequence elements for binding, in Escherichia coli these are multiple A-rich ARN or AAN repeats [7, 8].

cit12.CITATION: The physiological role of sRNAs in bacteria ranges from response to nutrient deprivation or envelope stress [9] [10] [11], to regulation of quorum sensing [12], virulence [13] and biofilm formation [14].

cit13.CITATION: The physiological role of sRNAs in bacteria ranges from response to nutrient deprivation or envelope stress [9] [10] [11], to regulation of quorum sensing [12], virulence [13] and biofilm formation [14].

cit14.CITATION: The physiological role of sRNAs in bacteria ranges from response to nutrient deprivation or envelope stress [9] [10] [11], to regulation of quorum sensing [12], virulence [13] and biofilm formation [14].

cit15.CITATION: The physiological role of sRNAs in bacteria ranges from response to nutrient deprivation or envelope stress [9] [10] [11], to regulation of quorum sensing [12], virulence [13] and biofilm formation [14].

cit16.CITATION: The physiological role of sRNAs in bacteria ranges from response to nutrient deprivation or envelope stress [9] [10] [11], to regulation of quorum sensing [12], virulence [13] and biofilm formation [14].

cit17.CITATION: The physiological role of sRNAs in bacteria ranges from response to nutrient deprivation or envelope stress [9] [10] [11], to regulation of quorum sensing [12], virulence [13] and biofilm formation [14].

cit18.CITATION: Burkholderia cenocepacia is a member of the Burkholderia cepacia complex (Bcc), a group of closely related opportunistic pathogens, which can infect immunocompromized individuals [15].

cit19.CITATION: In particular in cystic fibrosis, Bcc bacteria can cause chronic and often severe lung infections, which can lead to bacteremia and eventually death [16].

cit20.CITATION: The genome of B. cenocepacia is large (approx. 8 Mb, with 7261 annotated coding sequences, six sets of rRNA genes and 74 tRNAs), has a high GC-content (67 %) and consists of multiple replicons [17].

cit21.CITATION: The genomes of Burkholderia sp. display high plasticity and only approx. 50 % of the annotated coding sequences in strain J2315 have orthologues across the genus Burkholderia [17].

cit22.CITATION: The level of orthology to other Burkholderia species is largest for replicon 1, with smaller replicons showing progressively more divergence [17].

cit23.CITATION: The sRNA inventory of B. cenocepacia J2315 has been investigated by transcription start site analysis [18].

cit24.CITATION: Several small RNAs were highly expressed in B. cenocepacia J2315 biofilms, among them were four sibling sRNAs with a size of 57 to 92 nt [19].

cit25.CITATION: The homologous region of the four sibling sRNAs consists of two hairpin loops with pyrimidine-rich sequences in singlestranded domains of the predicted secondary structure [19].

cit26.CITATION: Computational prediction suggested that NcS27 targets genes that are involved in transport and metabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids and aromatic compounds [19].

cit27.CITATION: B. cenocepacia strains (Table S1, available in the online version of this article) were routinely grown and maintained in a phosphate buffered medium (basal salt medium, BSM [20]) containing yeast extract (5 g l -1), casamino acids (2 g l -1) and 0.5 % (wt/vol) glycerol as a carbon source (BSM-O [20]), or in LB broth (Lysogeny broth, Lennox formulation, 10 g l -1 tryptone, 5 g l -1 yeast extract, 5 g l -1 NaCl).

cit28.CITATION: For overexpressing NcS27, the full-size sRNA was amplified and cloned into a vector with a rhamnose-inducible promoter [21], modified to remove the ribosome-binding site and start codons [22].

cit29.CITATION: For overexpressing NcS27, the full-size sRNA was amplified and cloned into a vector with a rhamnose-inducible promoter [21], modified to remove the ribosome-binding site and start codons [22].

cit30.CITATION: For silencing NcS27, nucleotides 23 to 72 of the full-size sRNA were amplified and cloned into the vector in reverse orientation [19].

cit31.CITATION: A ncS27 deletion mutant, Δ27, was constructed by allelic recombination as described by Aubert et al. [23].

cit32.CITATION: Every compound was tested in at least two biological replicates, unless no growth was observed and the respective compound was also not metabolized in previous BIOLOG experiments [24].

cit33.CITATION: Global alignments of ncS27 homologues were generated using LocARNA, with default parameters [25].

cit34.CITATION: The NcS27 secondary structure was predicted and drawn with StructureEditor version 1.0 [26].

cit35.CITATION: The CopraRNA algorithm [27] was used for computational target prediction.

cit36.CITATION: The MEME algorithm [28] was used for motif search in mRNA sequences.

cit37.CITATION: The 5′UTR to a maximum of 150 nt (transcription start site data from [18]) and 50 nt upstream of the start of selected genes were used as input (Table S3).

cit38.CITATION: The annotation and functional categorization of genes of interest was verified, considering the context of surroundings annotated genes, using the conserved domain database [29], the Pfam 31.0 database [30] and the fitness browser (http://fit.genomics.lbl.gov/cgi-bin/myFrontPage.cgi [31]).

cit39.CITATION: The annotation and functional categorization of genes of interest was verified, considering the context of surroundings annotated genes, using the conserved domain database [29], the Pfam 31.0 database [30] and the fitness browser (http://fit.genomics.lbl.gov/cgi-bin/myFrontPage.cgi [31]).

cit40.CITATION: The annotation and functional categorization of genes of interest was verified, considering the context of surroundings annotated genes, using the conserved domain database [29], the Pfam 31.0 database [30] and the fitness browser (http://fit.genomics.lbl.gov/cgi-bin/myFrontPage.cgi [31]).

cit41.CITATION: RNA quantification, quality assessment, rRNA depletion and library preparation were performed as described before [22].

cit42.CITATION: The READemption pipeline [32] was used for mapping the reads to the B. cenocepacia J2315 reference genome (accession numbers AM747720, AM747721, AM747722, AM774723 [17]) and for differential expression analysis.

cit43.CITATION: The READemption pipeline [32] was used for mapping the reads to the B. cenocepacia J2315 reference genome (accession numbers AM747720, AM747721, AM747722, AM774723 [17]) and for differential expression analysis.

cit44.CITATION: The pipeline uses Segemehl [33] as mapping algorithm and Deseq2 [34] for expression comparison.

cit45.CITATION: The pipeline uses Segemehl [33] as mapping algorithm and Deseq2 [34] for expression comparison.

cit46.CITATION: Peptides were analysed by LC-MS/MS (liquid chromatography combined with mass spectrometry, using two mass analysers) analysis on an ABSciex TripleTOF 5600 system as described by Depluverez et al. [35].

cit47.CITATION: MaxQuant [36] was used for protein identification.

cit48.CITATION: The search results were, after normalization based on the total intensity, quantitatively analysed using the Perseus software [37].

cit49.CITATION: qPCR was performed as described before [19], using the GoTaq qPCR Master Mix (Promega).

cit50.SECTION: Conservation of structure, sequence and synteny of ncS27 in the order Burkholderiales
cit50.CITATION: Differential RNA-Seq data predicted that NcS27 is cleaved between position 29 and 30 ([18], Fig. 1).

cit51.SECTION: Conservation of structure, sequence and synteny of ncS27 in the order Burkholderiales
cit51.CITATION: The 5′ and 3′ ends of the full-size transcript were previously confirmed (by rapid amplification of cDNA ends [19]).

cit52.SECTION: Growth of overexpression and silencing mutants on single carbon compounds
cit52.CITATION: Because target prediction suggested a role of NcS27 in the metabolism of a variety of carbon compounds, growth curves in minimal medium with single carbon compounds as a source of carbon and energy were performed to investigate whether the effect of NcS27 overexpression and silencing on growth rate, as observed in LB medium [19], was substrate dependent.

cit53.CITATION: Expression changes of known sRNAs [19] were assessed by qPCR.

cit54.CITATION: Differential sequencing indicated that NcS27 is processed after nucleotide 29, resulting in a double-hairpin structure, which is very similar to that of the three siblings [19].

cit55.CITATION: The consensus sequence of the putative cleavage site (GM↓AUG) bears similarities to that of the RNase E cleavage site in E. coli (RN↓WUU) [38].

cit56.CITATION: The conserved putative target recognition site is rather short, which is not unusual for trans-encoded sRNAs [39].

cit57.CITATION: The B. cenocepacia J2315 genome encodes for two Hfq homologues [17], and NcS27 possesses the long stretch of U residues at its 3′ end, which is necessary for binding to Hfq in E. coli [40].

cit58.CITATION: The B. cenocepacia J2315 genome encodes for two Hfq homologues [17], and NcS27 possesses the long stretch of U residues at its 3′ end, which is necessary for binding to Hfq in E. coli [40].

cit59.CITATION: Computational target prediction generally results in a large proportion of false positives [27] because of the short seed regions.

cit60.CITATION: This could be caused by indirect effects of NcS27 regulation, e.g. via changes in transcriptional regulator abundance or by outcompeting other sRNAs for Hfq binding [41].

cit61.CITATION: All siblings contain the identical conserved 7 nt long target recognition site sequence in a single-stranded region, they consequently have a large overlap in predicted targets [19] and appear redundant.

cit62.CITATION: Three of the siblings, including NcS27, also harbour the same upstream motif [19], and are upregulated under the same growth arrest-related conditions, biofilm, stationary phase in rich medium and in low nutrient medium.

cit63.CITATION: Many sRNAs occur as siblings, either organized as tandems in the same genomic location or, like in the case of the quorum sensing regulating sRNAs Qrr1-5 in Vibrio sp., in distinct genomic locations [42].

cit64.CITATION: Functional redundancy might also be behind the lack of phenotypic difference of the ncS27 deletion mutant to the wild-type, which is typical for sRNA deletion mutants [43] and the reason for conducting overexpression experiments for phenotyping.

cit65.CITATION: Predicted targets BCAL0207, hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid dioxygenase hppD, and BCAL0650, indolepyruvate ferredoxin oxidoreductase ior (a large gene with similarities to both iorA and iorB in archaea [44]), were differentially expressed on both the transcriptome and proteome level.

cit66.CITATION: BCAL0207 (HppD) is involved in tyrosine degradation via the homogentisate pathway (Fig. 9 [45]) and the BCAL0650 homologue in Paraburkholderia phytofirmans is necessary for growth on phenylalanine [31].

cit67.CITATION: BCAL0207 (HppD) is involved in tyrosine degradation via the homogentisate pathway (Fig. 9 [45]) and the BCAL0650 homologue in Paraburkholderia phytofirmans is necessary for growth on phenylalanine [31].

cit68.CITATION: B. cenocepacia degrades phenylalanine via the phenylacetic acid (PAA) degradation pathway, which is the central pathway for aromatic compound degradation in Burkholderia sp [46].

cit69.CITATION: The homogentisate degradation pathway is not functioning in strain J2315 due to an amino acid substitution in BCAL3184, homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase HmgA [47].

cit70.CITATION: Another possible route is the homoprotocatechuate pathway via 4-hydroxyphenyl acetyl-CoA (Fig. 9 [48]).

cit71.CITATION: Predicted target BCAL0206, an indolepyruvate ferredoxin oxidoreductase homologous to BCAL0650 (50 % amino acid identity), is not essential for phenylalanine degradation in P. phytofirmans [31].

cit72.CITATION: For example, the B. cenocepacia J2315 genome encodes for two paralogues of paaK with different substrate specificities and affinities [49].

cit73.CITATION: Having two paralogues of ior could enable the bacterium to convert a broader spectrum of substituted phenylpyruvate derivatives, or possibly indolepyruvate, an intermediate of tryptophan degradation [50].

cit74.CITATION: This activation of phhB and phhA (Fig. 9) might be due to a probably increased intracellular concentration of phenylalanine during NcS27 overexpression [51].

cit75.CITATION: The PAA degradation pathway is important for virulence and intracellular survival of B. cenocepacia [52], and its activation can increase antibiotic resistance to meropenem [53], indicating its universal utility.

cit76.CITATION: The PAA degradation pathway is important for virulence and intracellular survival of B. cenocepacia [52], and its activation can increase antibiotic resistance to meropenem [53], indicating its universal utility.

cit77.CITATION: This is analogous to the AbcR1 and AbcR2 (for ABC regulator) sibling sRNAs in members of the order Rhizobiales [42].

cit78.CITATION: In Agrobacterium tumefaciens, AbcR1 regulates the periplasmic-binding proteins of several ABC transporters and also pyruvate kinase [54].

cit79.CITATION: The repression of growth on numerous carbon compounds by NcS27 is also analogous to Spot42, the E. coli sRNA encoded by the spf gene [55].

cit80.CITATION: Spf regulates the expression of genes involved in uptake and metabolism of non-favoured carbon sources, and plays an important role in catabolite repression in E. coli [56].

cit81.CITATION: Its best known target is galK, the downregulation of which represses the galactose metabolism operon [55].

cit82.CITATION: The genes for metabolizing these compounds are present in the B. cenocepacia genome [57], but the metabolic flux is probably too low to sustain growth on these compounds as the sole source of carbon and energy.

cit83.CITATION: ncS27 and its siblings were first described as genes that are toxic to bacteria [58] because expressing these sequences in E. coli completely inhibited its growth (hence their designation in the RFAM database as 'toxic small RNAs').

cit84.CITATION: ncS27 and its siblings were putatively named 'double hairpin RNAs' in a previous publication [19].
